column4: Maybe someone can answer this: There's xnest and XDCMP to start a completely new session remotely, or vino/vinagre/vnc for taking over an existing local session, but is there anything like windows Terminal Services which allows you to start a new session and "disconnect" so that it stays running in the background?  Like XDCMP with nohup somehow?
vncserver can do that
for multiple users or for a specific X session?
you can start a new X display for the VNC session, and keep it going after you disconnect
googling vncserver now... don't recall this quite being as straightforward as that... thanks!
if you want the session accessible from teh console, it's not as straight forward
no I'm thinking like what tsm for windows does where you have a client that does the initial connect and you get a "login" screen or resume your current session
Xvnc is an X extension that shares the default display over VNC
I see - that's what I thought for the vnc server: it's started as the specific user and waits for that user to connect, not as arbitrary user

but, there again, it's the default console, not a remote session that can be used at the same time as others.  Say I want user1 and user2 to both be able to log in remotely and disconnect/resume sessions independently.  To make it more complicated, user1 and user2 can be any arbitrary user on the system
I'm not entirely sure how to do that with VNC

that's just it - I cannot actually find a suitable replacement for Microsoft's terminal service manager under linux and I am really baffled that Microsoft can make their OS more multi-user usable than the Linux community can.  I'm actually stumped here
XDMCP can probably do what you want
close, but if the connection drops, XDMCP completely closes the session - hard
that's why I started the question the way I did.
have you seen http://linuxreviews.org/howtos/xvnc/ ?
looking at it now...
I'm not sure if you can make that setup keep a session alive after a disconnect and have the user re-connect to it again later
Wow.  That might do it, but it's not going to be easy to streamline the client connection process :(
Wait!  I think freenx is what I might be wanting :)
fyi: http://freenx.berlios.de/
thanks, I've heard of it before, but not really familiar
or better yet the NoMachine (commercial but with free version) http://www.nomachine.com/select-package.php?os=linux&id=1
